executive_summary: Nearly half of this industry's products are made of aluminum; the remainder are made of iron and steel. Due to considerable volatility in the price of steel and aluminum sheet and other inputs, industry profitability has fluctuated over the five years to 2021. The prices of key inputs have increased during the latter half of the five-year period, raising purchase costs for industry operators and subsequently hampering average profit margins.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many of the larger companies have acquired smaller competitors in an effort to expand geographic reach. The number of enterprises is expected to increase an annualized 1.3% to 288 companies over the five years to 2021. Industry employment is also expected to grow an annualized 3.3% to 36,258 workers.

Imports satisfy only 9.5% of domestic demand but are estimated to grow an annualized 6.2% to $804.6 million over the five years to 2021. The value of exports is estimated to decline at an annualized rate of 2.5% to $201.6 million over the same period due to the strong US dollar.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry is expected to continue growing over the five years to 2026, with revenue forecast to grow at an annualized rate of 1.1% to $8.3 billion.

While overall construction value is expected to exhibit strong initial growth, it is projected to only increase an annualized 1.8% over the outlook period due to expected interest rate hikes tempering growth in the latter half.

Steel and aluminum input prices are expected to stabilize as industrial activity rebounds. Employment is forecast to rise at an annualized 1.6% to 39,295 workers, while the number of enterprises is expected to grow at 1.5% to 311 operators over the five years to 2026.

Import penetration is expected to continue rising, with imports forecast to increase at an annualized 0.8% to $836.2 million. Exports are estimated to grow at 1.3% to $215.4 million over the next five years.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures metal doors and door frames. Industry products are primarily made of aluminum and steel and are used in a variety of residential and nonresidential applications, including fire doors and safety exits. This industry does not manufacture doors with a wood core.
key_trends: Iron and steel doors are extensively used in multifamily residential units
Due to considerable volatility in the price of steel and aluminum sheet and other inputs, industry profitability has fluctuated
The dollar's sharp appreciation, coupled with weakening demand from Canada and other major trade partners, has hindered export sales
The price of steel and aluminum inputs is expected to stabilize
Competition will be heightened by the continued penetration of imports into the domestic market
Large operators enable customers to select all aspects of the metal door desired
Demand for metal doors will remain high due to aesthetic, durability and security reasons

market_segmentation.segment_description: The residential market includes single family homes, multifamily housing complexes, town homes and multistory housing residences. It demands aluminum doors for exterior applications and iron/steel overhead doors for garages.

This market includes offices, retail spaces, schools, religious centers and municipalities. It demands a variety of metal doors like swinging, sliding, aluminum and steel doors based on factors like aesthetics and fire resistance.
This market includes warehouses, factories and industrial facilities. It drives demand primarily for strong, durable and fire-resistant iron and steel doors.
Top export destinations include Canada, Mexico, Bahamas and Argentina. The value of exports has decreased over the past five years.

products_and_services.product_description: Aluminum doors used in residential applications like showers, patios and some indoor spaces.
Aluminum doors used in nonresidential applications like offices and retail spaces.
Iron and steel doors used in residential applications, primarily overhead doors for garages.
Iron and steel doors used in nonresidential applications like commercial buildings, institutions and industrial facilities.
Door frames of all metal types including aluminum and iron, used for renewing or renovating existing doors.
Overhead metal garage doors used in residential applications.

tier_1_suppliers: Steel Rolling & Drawing in the US
Screw, Nut & Bolt Manufacturing in the US
Ferrous Metal Foundry Products in the US
Nonferrous Metal Rolling & Alloying in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Iron & Steel Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Industrial Building Construction in the US
Commercial Building Construction in the US
Municipal Building Construction in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for metal doors is based on the macroeconomic environment.
Demand is influenced by weather conditions, as metal doors can protect against natural disasters.
The quality of the doors produced affects demand.
Demand for substitute products like wood and vinyl doors impacts demand for metal doors.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports have continued to encroach into the domestic market, taking share from domestic manufacturers.
Much of the imports come from Canada and Mexico which share borders and free trade agreements with the US, incurring low transportation costs.
A growing share of imports is coming from China, the world's largest steel producer and low-cost manufacturer, primarily on the basis of price.
Exports are low and mostly restricted to nearby markets like Canada due to the appreciation of the US dollar making US products more expensive.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest percentage of both establishments (around 30%) and population (around 20%).
The West region follows with approximately 15% of establishments and around 25% of the population.
The Great Lakes region has around 15% of establishments and 15% of the population.
The Mid-Atlantic region has roughly 10% of establishments and 15% of the population.
The Southwest region has around 10% of establishments and 10% of the population.
The Plains region has approximately 10% of establishments and 5% of the population.
The Rocky Mountains region has around 5% of establishments and 5% of the population.
The New England region has the lowest percentage of both establishments (around 5%) and population (around 5%).

regulations_points.regulation_description: The industry must follow EPA regulations on use, storage, discharge and disposal of hazardous chemicals during manufacturing.
Fire- and wind-rated doors must meet requirements from building codes and testing standards set by agencies like NFPA and ANSI.
Foreign sales are subject to restrictions like the Export Administration Act which controls items that could impact national security.
Federal, state and local policies imposed restrictions on business activities to slow the spread of COVID-19, disrupting industry operations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The capital intensity level is low, which decreases barriers to entry.
The industry has a low level of concentration, which decreases barriers to entry.

basis_points.basis_description: Companies compete on the basis of price as well as quality, technical expertise and innovation.
Manufacturers maintain competitive position through substantial investment in research and development.
Operators compete on product design, style, and introducing new cutting-edge products.
Companies compete based on their connections with contractors, architects and designers who influence supply contracts.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The top four companies are estimated to generate only 11.3% of total revenue in 2021.
Assa Abloy is estimated to hold the greatest market position at 8.8% of industry revenue in 2021.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Most operators are small and local
concentration_points.concentration_description: The majority of operators are small and locally-based, serving nearby construction markets.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit is intricately tied to the strength of demand from downstream markets and movements in the price of key inputs such as aluminum and steel.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wage costs high due to large workforce
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wage costs are high because the workforce is large; the industry is expected to employ 36,258 workers, with an average wage of $54,681 per employee.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase costs volatile due to metal prices
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs have exhibited exceptional volatility during the five-year period due to fluctuations in aluminum and steel prices.
Depreciation costs are projected to experience upward pressure as the industry relies more heavily on automated production methods.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low capital expenditure compared to wages
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry exhibits low capital intensity, with operators estimated to spend $0.06 on depreciable assets for every $1.00 spent on labor in 2019.
Capital expenditure includes technologies such as computer-aided design, metal extrusion, and metal stamping machinery.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Revenue growth tied to construction activity
volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue largely grew at a consistent pace since 2016 on account of an overall increase in the value of construction, the industry's main market.
Metal prices, a key determinant of input costs and selling prices, have remained volatile and induced some fluctuation in sales.
The industry hit substantial turbulence during the COVID-19 pandemic as downstream consumers put off purchases and some states designated industry activities as nonessential.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Technological development focuses on maintaining a competitive cost structure by controlling manufacturing and operating expenses.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Product innovation driven by customer needs
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The needs of downstream industries play a critical role in shaping innovation among manufacturers in areas like stronger doors and new materials.
The industry has invested in global standardization, information technology infrastructure and product development to drive innovation.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Imports do not account for a significant share of industry revenue and do not impact domestic demand in the industry.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Majority of operators manufacture standardized products that are sold across various downstream markets.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years? Can your company benefit from input prices that are at elevated levels?
FAQs.answer: Volatility in metal prices impacted top-line selling prices. however, the largest operators have sustained their margins over the past five years.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: Large operators in the industry have manufacturing locations across the world.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology?
FAQs.answer: Technology in the industry has remained steady over the past five years but automation has increased slightly across the board.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in technology printing to establish a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Technological investments by both small and large operators have remained steady with not a large push in capital expenditure.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently? What new regulations has your company encountered with the pandemic and have they impacted production?
FAQs.answer: Regulatory expenses have largely remained steady in the industry over the past five years. Companies have recently been forced to comply with new health and safety regulations that have arisen due to the coronavirus pandemic. International tariffs in the industry have largely remained steady despite recent tariff changes.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margin compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profitability in the industry has decreased over the five years to 2021 on account of increasing purchase costs.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Input prices, such as the price of steel, have increased significantly as of recent. Industry-relevant metal prices are expected to remain at elevated levels over the coming years.

FAQs.question: Are you currently located near key markets? How do you cater to local consumers?
FAQs.answer: As the majority of products manufactured in this industry are standardized and interchangeable, customers are likely to buy from local manufacturers so they can minimize transport costs.

FAQs.question: Is your brand name well established?
FAQs.answer: Market position and brand recognition are key marketing tools for expanding a company's customer base, leveraging its distribution network and increasing its market share.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain product quality?
FAQs.answer: A supplier should ensure that the products being sold meet numerous quality standards; this is especially important for fire doors and other security doors.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in the homeownership rate?
FAQs.answer: The homeownership rate represents the proportion of households that own the home in which they live.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuating steel prices affect your company?
FAQs.answer: Steel doors are the other primary industry offering. Therefore, steel represents a major purchase cost. Rising steel prices would generally lead to falling profitability unless operators were able to pass on the entire cost increase to consumers.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in residential construction?
FAQs.answer: The residential market is the largest market for metal doors. This market has continued to grow substantially during the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic, but is expected to slow over the coming years as interest rates tick higher.
